quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam A Session 1
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam A Session 1
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 1) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Pitrakkou-23
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following statements are consistent with the Standard relating to referral fees?

Statement 1 A member must disclose the nature of the benefit for referrals of clients and their estimated value.
Statement 2 Disclosures of referral fees allow clients to evaluate any partiality shown in any recommendation of services.
Statement 3 A member is required to advise the client only after entry into a formal agreement for services of benefits received for the recommendation of services provided by the member.

answerFeedback.3719c34d-8d02-48fe-827c-ffe7a348d4b8: Incorrect because according to Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, appropriate disclosure means that members and candidates must advise the client or prospective client, before entry into any formal agreement for services, of any benefit given or received for the recommendation of any services provided by the member or candidate. Therefore Statement 3 is incorrect as this information should be provided before and not only after the formal agreement is in place. The remaining two Statements are correct, as per the rationale for the correct response.
answerFeedback.5b90d691-9fb7-457f-9d21-b484032bc0cf: Incorrect because both Statement 1 and Statement 2 are correct.
answerFeedback.d480e64a-7372-4f4d-a42f-4d3611ea48e1:
Correct because according to Standard VI (C), Referral Fees, the responsibility of members and candidates to inform their employer, clients, and prospective clients of any benefit received for referrals of customers and clients. Such disclosures allow clients or employers to evaluate (1) any partiality shown in any recommendation of services and (2) the full cost of the services. Members and candidates must disclose when they pay a fee or provide compensation to others who have referred prospective clients to the member or candidate.

Appropriate disclosure means that members and candidates must advise the client or prospective client, before entry into any formal agreement for services, of any benefit given or received for the recommendation of any services provided by the member or candidate. In addition, the member or candidate must disclose the nature of the consideration or benefit—for example, flat fee or percentage basis, one-time or continuing benefit, based on performance, benefit in the form of provision of research or other noncash benefit—together with the estimated dollar value.

entry.title: ITEM_20210122018
entry.itemBody: When first becoming compliant with the GIPS standards, an investment firm with 12 years of investment performance history must initially present a minimum of:

answerFeedback.2ea63b79-3fe9-4d5b-9a6f-c0a3206a805d: Correct because a firm is required to initially present, at a minimum, five years of annual investment performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards.
answerFeedback.de6616aa-698c-4543-bf35-a4d15805d032: Incorrect because a firm is required to initially present, at a minimum, five years of annual investment performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards. Firms are then required to build up to a 10-year record. Showing the full 12-year record is optional but not required.
answerFeedback.f0fc9473-5ec5-4e34-9b98-9cd2ebd1ba26: Incorrect because a firm is required to initially present, at a minimum, five years of annual investment performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards. Firms are then required to build up to a 10-year record.

entry.title: ITEM_20170420071
entry.itemBody: Pia Nilsson is a sole proprietor investment advisor. An economic recession has reduced the number of clients she advises and caused revenues to decline. As a result, Nilsson has not paid her CFA Institute membership dues for the past two years. When a national financial publication recently interviewed Nilsson, she indicated that up until two years ago she had been a CFA charterholder and a CFA Institute member in good standing. In addition, she stated the completion of the CFA Program enhanced her portfolio management skills and enabled her to achieve superior returns on behalf of her clients. Which of Nilsson's following actions most likely violated the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct?

answerFeedback.16d88ca3-1d55-4b91-835d-6cdae390e7cf: Correct because according to Standard VII(B), Reference to CFA Institute, the CFA Designation, and the CFA Program, it is a violation to claim that the CFA charter helped her to achieve superior returns.
answerFeedback.6c28784d-8c9b-4fa6-8c34-6b2227f2f8b9: Incorrect because it is not a violation to not pay fees if the person does not claim to be a CFA charterholder or a member of the CFA Institute.
answerFeedback.c6eff1ed-5302-4267-a6be-36c4cd768ff9: Incorrect because it is appropriate to claim that being a charterholder has improved her portfolio management skills.

choices.itemBody: A. Nonpayment of CFA Institute membership dues
B. Attributing her superior returns to participation in the CFA Program
C. Indicating that being a CFA charterholder has enhanced her portfolio management skills

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Agarwal-17
entry.itemBody: Ritu Jain, CFA, is preparing to leave her firm and join a new employer. Prior to leaving the firm, Jain calls all her clients informing them of her decision to leave. When asked by the clients, Jain states lack of confidence in the firm's leadership as the reason for her departure and also mentions that more employees are likely to leave soon. Jain has violated the Standard(s) relating:

answerFeedback.9b7cd9d8-fc37-4fb0-97ed-af3df4ad88d7: Correct because Standard IV(A), Loyalty states that CFA Institute members and candidates must act for the benefit of their employer and not otherwise cause harm to their employer and Jain violates her duty of loyalty to her employer by making disparaging and harmful statements about the firm to its clients. Jain can call her clients to inform of her decision but cannot make disparaging statements about her employer. Also according to Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. No client related information is being disclosed and information pertaining to an employer is not covered by this Standard. Hence only the Standard relating to preservation of confidentiality has been violated.
answerFeedback.afd387da-70d6-490b-a812-d92ca951e528: Incorrect because according to Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. No client related information is being disclosed and information pertaining to an employer is not covered by this Standard. This Standard is not violated.
answerFeedback.db4de4d7-241a-492c-b4c6-d7e820f77cf6: Incorrect because according to Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients. No client related information is being disclosed and information pertaining to an employer is not covered by this Standard. This Standard is not violated.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Ethics-Squires-06
entry.itemBody:
Harbor Asset Management (HAM) manages both domestic and global portfolios for its clients. HAM includes the following statements in its promotional materials:

• Statement 1: All investment consultants retained by HAM endorse the GIPS standards.

• Statement 2: All domestic portfolios managed by HAM are in compliance with the GIPS standards.

• Statement 3: The objective of the GIPS standards is to eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence by prospective investors.

Which of HAM's statements is most consistent with the GIPS standards?

answerFeedback.5aa72120-ee9e-4fcf-8aa4-b8fdcd7729c5: Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, compliance is a firm-wide process that cannot be achieved on a single product or composite.
answerFeedback.ada3ec7f-dde4-4c9b-b739-1070ff232252: Correct because according to the GIPS standards, investment consultants can claim to endorse the GIPS standards.
answerFeedback.d6c2828c-91f9-470d-956e-7bdf953d6646: Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, the GIPS standards certainly do not eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence on the part of the client or investor.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-13
entry.itemBody: Jonas Balsys, CFA, has a prospective client, Edith Clancy, who mentions that she donates to environmental causes. Balsys mentions Clancy to a friend who works for an environmental agency. The next week, Balsys prepares an IPS for Clancy. Clancy does not disclose information about assets outside of her ESG investments. Balsys prepares the IPS based on the partial information provided by Clancy and enters into a formal agreement with her. Balsys has most likely violated the Standard relating to:

answerFeedback.6fb065b5-7bbd-4c14-b40d-0a75f60edd92: Incorrect because according to Standard III(C), Suitability, if clients withhold information about their financial portfolios, the suitability analysis conducted by members and candidates cannot be expected to be complete; it must be based on the information provided.
answerFeedback.6fd2d9e6-9127-4dac-82ba-4921acda91b2: Correct because according to Standard III(E), Preservation of Confidentiality, members and candidates preserve the confidentiality of information communicated to them by their clients, prospective clients, and former clients.
answerFeedback.8e73ccea-68ba-4e4e-b185-049708a947ce: Incorrect because Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, requires to exercise diligence, independence, and thoroughness in analyzing investments, making investment recommendations, and taking investment actions.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01103
entry.itemBody: John McCay, CFA, is an analyst who has prepared a report on the cable industry based on research from a variety of sources and analysts. He compiles these findings to form his own opinion and distributes the report to clients without acknowledging his sources. McCay has violated the Standards by:

answerFeedback.6f7a700a-883e-4d6f-8dd7-9e66861d29fe: Incorrect because McCay did not violate Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis, which states that in providing an investment service, members and candidates typically use a variety of resources, including company reports, third-party research, and results from quantitative models. A reasonable basis is formed through a balance of these resources appropriate for the security or decision being analyzed. There is no indication that McCay lacked reasonable basis for his conclusions.
answerFeedback.9217ddc6-12c4-4cb8-9fe3-7f5436798b01: Incorrect because in their work, members and candidates draw from a variety of sources in reviewing information used in the investment decision-making process. According to Standard I(C), using this information in itself is not a violation of the Standards, as long as these sources are properly acknowledged. Members and candidates should disclose whether the research being presented to clients comes from another source—from either within or outside the member's or candidate's firm. This allows clients to understand who has the expertise behind the report or whether the work is being done by the analyst, other members of the firm, or an outside party. Therefore, McCay did not violate this Standard by incorporating other analysts' research into his own work.
answerFeedback.9cb73a4d-b850-4732-83aa-18de622f0127: Correct because according to Standard I(C), Misrepresentation, in order to prevent plagiarism, members and candidates may use and distribute other sources' research as long as they do not represent themselves as the authors. Members should disclose and cite the sources of their information, so that the client is not misled as to the level of expertise behind the report. One of the most egregious practices in violation of this standard is the preparation of research reports based on multiple sources of information without acknowledging the sources. Therefore, McCay violated this Standard by failing to cite the work of others.

choices.itemBody: A. failing to cite the work of others.
B. failing to have a reasonable basis for his conclusions.
C. incorporating other analysts' research into his own work.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Ethics-Kennan-08
entry.itemBody: According to the GIPS standards, a firm’s definition of discretion establishes criteria to judge which of the following?

answerFeedback.42a8181f-784f-4e8b-8e7b-53d30c53ef61: Incorrect because firms may not choose portfolios to include in a composite based on performance: the requirement to create, use and maintain composites is designed to prevent firms from cherry-picking—using the best-performing accounts to represent the performance of an investment strategy.
answerFeedback.4b33abbb-e20e-43c5-bb90-368f4d647893: Correct because the firm’s definition of discretion establishes criteria to judge which portfolios must be included in a composite and is based on the firm’s ability to implement its investment strategies.
answerFeedback.d3abb078-0170-4fba-8152-70288958d4b4: Incorrect because the causality is reversed; strategy determines discretion for portfolios, not vice versa The firm’s definition of discretion establishes criteria to judge which portfolios must be included in a composite and is based on the firm’s ability to implement its investment strategies.

choices.itemBody: B. Portfolios the firm must include in a composite
C. Accounts the firm may exclude based on performance criteria

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.04616830-9dac-4c10-89e3-020b693194f9: Incorrect because although laws frequently codify ethical actions, legal and ethical conduct are not always the same. Think about the diagram in Exhibit 1. Many types of conduct are both legal and ethical, but some conduct may be one and not the other. Some legal behaviors or activities may be considered unethical, and some behaviors or activi­ties considered ethical may be deemed illegal in certain jurisdictions.
answerFeedback.1b444be1-79b3-4d77-8dea-ca09796adf1c: Correct because although laws frequently codify ethical actions, legal and ethical conduct are not always the same. Think about the diagram in Exhibit 1. Many types of conduct are both legal and ethical, but some conduct may be one and not the other. Some legal behaviors or activities may be considered unethical, and some behaviors or activi­ties considered ethical may be deemed illegal in certain jurisdictions.
answerFeedback.d51c7b05-d649-4aed-a32e-3c0b573393a7: Incorrect because although laws frequently codify ethical actions, legal and ethical conduct are not always the same. Think about the diagram in Exhibit 1. Many types of conduct are both legal and ethical, but some conduct may be one and not the other. Some legal behaviors or activities may be considered unethical, and some behaviors or activi­ties considered ethical may be deemed illegal in certain jurisdictions.

choices.itemBody: C. Some legal activities may be unethical.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Ethics-Kennan-10
entry.itemBody: Employing an independent GIPS standards verifier:

answerFeedback.02a26f1e-ea7c-4ffa-a506-ba166ef4244b: Incorrect because the firm remains responsible for its claim of compliance. Firms that claim compliance with the GIPS standards are responsible for their claim of compliance and for maintaining that compliance.
answerFeedback.a0c7b0f9-5008-4d58-925e-a2221b1925a4: Correct because according to the GIPS standards once a firm claims compliance with the standards, they may voluntarily hire an independent third party to perform a verification in order to increase confidence in the firm’s claim of compliance.
answerFeedback.ab23e623-be99-4b0b-9613-47126b2d2e63: Incorrect because verification does not impact performance. Verification provides assurance on whether the firm’s policies and procedures related to composite and pooled fund maintenance, as well as the calculation, presentation, and distribution of performance, have been designed in compliance with the GIPS standards and have been implemented on a firm-wide basis.

choices.itemBody: A. improves the performance record of the firm's investment team.
B. increases confidence in the firm’s claim of compliance with the GIPS standards.
C. shifts responsibility for the firm's claim of compliance with the GIPS standards to the verifier.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Kennan-03
entry.itemBody: According to the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care, a member with control of client assets should submit to each client an itemized statement of their security holdings and transactions at least:

answerFeedback.0e743675-cb10-4080-8105-c13a9feb21df: Incorrect because Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, states that members should submit statements at least quarterly, not semi-annually, as described in the correct response rationale.
answerFeedback.29c17290-d636-492e-be9d-3207aded059b: Correct because according to Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, members and candidates with control of client assets should submit to each client, at least quarterly, an itemized statement showing the funds and securities in the custody or possession of the member or candidate plus all debits, credits, and transactions that occurred during the period.
answerFeedback.9386a8ed-3a84-408f-9901-63fae7ebceee: Incorrect because Standard III(A), Loyalty, Prudence, and Care, states that members should submit statements at least quarterly, not annually, as described in the correct response rationale.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-18
entry.itemBody: According to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, a member should encourage her employer to:

answerFeedback.0f28cc50-fd81-4187-a5a1-069401d182cc: Incorrect because only when compensation and incentives are firmly tied to client interests and how outcomes are achieved, rather than how much is generated for the firm, will employees work to achieve a culture of integrity.
answerFeedback.7b5c19ec-bb71-4dea-bd08-8c757bf11753: Incorrect because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, separating the code of ethics from compliance procedures will also reduce, if not eliminate, the legal terminology and “boilerplate” language that can make the under­lying ethical principles incomprehensible to the average person.
answerFeedback.e2ae1eea-0de3-4562-a0ee-f848951f382c: Correct because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with the Standard relating to responsibilities of supervisors, stand-alone codes of ethics should be written in plain language and should address general fiduciary concepts. They should be unencumbered by numerous detailed pro­cedures.

choices.itemBody: A. integrate a code of ethics into compliance procedures.
B. build incentive structures based on how much revenue is generated for the firm.
C. write a code of ethics in plain language and without numerous detailed procedures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Hambusch-21
entry.itemBody: Immediately after taking the CFA Level II exam, Tim Riley posts on social media broad topic areas that were not tested on the exam. He also posts an article on social media questioning the relevance of CFA Program for professional practice. Has Riley violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.6c444368-3536-4cfe-9b4c-afa3f2911aef: Incorrect because according to Standard VII (A), Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, examples of information that cannot be disclosed by candidates sitting for an exam include but are not limited to broad topical areas and formulas tested or not tested on the exam. Riley violates this Standard by posting on social media broad topical areas not tested on the exam.
answerFeedback.78677d83-eea7-4b72-9829-0c0dfc5540a5: Correct because according to Standard VII (A), Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, examples of information that cannot be disclosed by candidates sitting for an exam include but are not limited to broad topical areas and formulas tested or not tested on the exam. Riley violates this Standard by posting on social media broad topical areas not tested on the exam.
answerFeedback.c7bcf043-d9ba-4a9e-8def-290b8ed84cd8: Incorrect because Standard VII (A), Conduct as Participants in CFA Institute Programs, states that members and candidates must not engage in any conduct that compromises the reputation or integrity of CFA Institute or the CFA designation or the integrity, validity, or security of CFA Institute programs. However, this Standard does not prohibit candidates from voicing their opinion about CFA Program, in general.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, by posting broad topic areas not tested on the exam
C. Yes, by questioning the relevance of CFA Program for professional practice

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Ebeling-11
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is permitted according to the Standards? A member:

answerFeedback.2176fe27-55b0-48ab-86c9-9369e0e48bfa: Incorrect because information-based market manipulation includes transactions that artificially affect prices or volume to give the impression of activity or price movement in a financial instrument, which represent a diversion from the expectations of a fair and efficient market. Therefore, a member is not permitted to disseminate information to give the impression of increased liquidity of an asset.
answerFeedback.74b56f18-fefa-4615-b8b8-734a0b163635: Correct because Standard II(B) is not intended to preclude transactions undertaken on legitimate trading strategies based on perceived market inefficiencies. The intent of the action is critical to determining whether it is a violation of this standard. Therefore, a member is permitted to exploit market inefficiencies for personal trades.
answerFeedback.dadb2c64-28e7-4fb8-b9be-c26a742e9e34: Incorrect because information-based market manipulation includes securing a controlling, dominant position in a financial instrument to exploit and manipulate the price of a related derivative and/or the underlying asset. Therefore, a member is not permitted to secure a dominant position in an underlying asset to control the price of its derivative.

choices.itemBody: A. exploits market inefficiencies for personal trades.
B. disseminates information to give the impression of increased liquidity of an asset.
C. secures a dominant position in an underlying asset to control the price of its derivative.

entry.title: ITEM_20170420103
entry.itemBody: Sherry Buckner, CFA, manages equity accounts for government entities whose portfolios are classified as being conservative and risk averse. Since the objective of her clients is to maximize returns with the lowest possible risk, Buckner considers adding to their holdings a new, thinly traded, leveraged derivative product that she believes has the potential for high returns. To make her investment decision, Buckner relies upon comprehensive research from an investment bank with a solid reputation for top quality research. After her review of that research, Buckner positions her accounts so each has a 10% allocation to the derivative product. Did Buckner most likely violate any CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct by purchasing the derivative product for her clients?

answerFeedback.02956ce1-0b90-49f3-acd3-76d9fab020e8: Incorrect because Buckner violated Standard III(C), Suitability.
answerFeedback.3c99d309-8421-42e4-ab0c-5505294c1e15: Incorrect because Buckner relied upon comprehensive research from the investment bank so did not violate the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence and care.
answerFeedback.3eb489f2-c143-4b2f-942b-ec15e6a5f0ad: Correct because Buckner is in violation of Standard III(C), Suitability, since she did not consider issues such as the limited liquidity or any potential leverage of this new product when she invested a substantial percentage of her clients’ portfolios in these instruments.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to suitability
C. Yes, the Standard relating to loyalty, prudence, and care

entry.title: ITEM_20170420026
entry.itemBody: Adira Badawi, CFA, who owns a research and consulting company, is an independent board member of a leading cement manufacturer in a small local market. Because of Badawi’s expertise in the cement industry, a foreign cement manufacturer looking to enter the local market has hired him to undertake a feasibility study. Under what circumstances can Badawi most likely undertake the assignment without violating the Standards?

answerFeedback.1e8f48a1-2213-43a3-9041-d1adcbe3572a: Incorrect because the signing of confidentiality agreements does not necessarily provide full and fair disclosure of all matters that could reasonably be expected to impair Badawi’s independence and objectivity or interfere with respective duties to his clients as required by Standard VI(A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts.
answerFeedback.68f0d5ec-e136-41e2-9327-c61c8d920d56: Incorrect because written permission from both parties would be needed to provide full and fair disclosure of all matters that could reasonably be expected to impair their independence and objectivity or interfere with respective duties to their clients. The requirement to disclose under Standard VI (A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts, does not mandate that this be in writing. In fact, members and candidates have the responsibility of determining how often, in what manner, and in what particular circumstances the disclosure must be made.
answerFeedback.deff4654-b208-45b2-9c2b-5ad65698d0b0: Correct because making full and fair disclosure of all matters that could reasonably be expected to impair one’s independence and objectivity or interfere with respective duties to one’s clients is required by Standard VI(A), Avoid or Disclose Conflicts.

choices.itemBody: A. By making full disclosure to both companies
B. By receiving written permission from the local company
C. By signing confidentiality agreements with both companies

entry.title: ITEM_20170420055
entry.itemBody: While waiting in the business class lounge before boarding an airplane, Becca Msafari, CFA, an equity analyst, overhears a conversation by a group of senior managers, including members of the Board, from a large publicly listed bank. The managers discuss staff changes necessary to accommodate their regional expansion plans. Msafari hears several staff names mentioned. Under what circumstances could Msafari most likely use this information when making an investment recommendation to her clients?

answerFeedback.6e399211-a2ae-4f56-be45-067db970465d: Correct because in order to comply with Standard II(A), Material Nonpublic Information, a member or candidate cannot use material nonpublic information when making investment recommendations. The information overheard would be considered material only if any public announcement of the staff removal would be likely to move the share price of the bank. In this case, the discussed changes are unlikely to affect investor perception of the bank, so Msafari could use the information when making an investment recommendation.
answerFeedback.862c4191-71fd-4e14-9e9a-f524a9e143b6: Incorrect because if the staff under discussion for possible termination are in low-level positions, the information is unlikely to be considered material.
answerFeedback.a781d859-67c2-4593-9fa4-d5023796a6f3: Incorrect because the absence of specific names being mentioned does not necessarily make the information non-material when disclosed to clients prior to any public dissemination.

choices.itemBody: B. If she does not breach the confidentiality of names of staff
C. If the discussed changes are unlikely to affect investor perception of the bank

entry.title: ITEM_20170420166
entry.itemBody: According to the Code and Standards regarding knowledge of laws and regulations, CFA Institute members and candidates must:

answerFeedback.631a29d1-8c73-4c6a-a4d2-e728cafd2913: Incorrect because members and candidates do not have such a requirement under the Standards.
answerFeedback.82343d7c-2651-4dd6-a9d0-4ea90264d9a8: Incorrect because Standard I(A) does require members and candidates to become legal experts. While an understanding of laws and regulations is required, members and candidates can rely on legal counsel and compliance to be subject matter experts in these areas.
answerFeedback.d2d63256-463b-481d-a5cd-6660a636eafb: Correct because Standard I(A) requires members and candidates to understand applicable laws and regulations in those countries where they trade or conduct business. While an understanding of laws and regulations is required, members and candidates can rely on legal counsel and compliance to be subject matter experts in these areas.

choices.itemBody: A. understand the relevant regulations for all the countries where they trade securities.
B. have detailed knowledge of all the laws that could potentially govern the member’s activities.
C. spend a minimum of five hours per calendar year on continuing education activities related to applicable laws and regulations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Augulyte-06
entry.itemBody: Lucie Hilbert, CFA, offers premium services to clients for an additional fee. She offers the premium services only by email to all of her clients. One client, who previously inquired about premium services, does not receive the offer due to a technical problem with the client's email system. One week later Hilbert makes an investment in an IPO on behalf of her clients. The issue is oversubscribed, so she excludes her sister, a regular fee-paying client of Hilbert's firm, to free up shares for other clients. Has Hilbert most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.16bbed77-a8ab-46f5-a97d-a73e57b620cb: Correct because according to Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, if the investment professional’s family-member accounts are managed similarly to the accounts of other clients of the firm, the family-member accounts should not be excluded from buying such shares. In this case, Hilbert's sister is a regular fee-paying client, thus should not be excluded.
answerFeedback.22ce774b-d42d-488c-872d-3fb1d21ad497: Incorrect because Hilbert violated Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.f8be4303-7a24-4101-a348-a4994bd92bec: Incorrect because Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, addresses member and candidate conduct with respect to communicating with clients.  According to this Standard, a presentation of information can be made via any means of communication, including in-person recommendation or description, telephone conversation, media broadcast, or transmission by computer (e.g., on the internet).

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to fair dealing
C. Yes, the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Kennan-07
entry.itemBody: Jessica Ash, CFA, Ryan Boyd, CFA and Jeffrey Cook, CFA, discuss how to remain consistent with the Standard relating to performance presentation practices. Ash states: "Members must apply the GIPS Standards to meet their obligations." Boyd says: "GIPS application is not mandatory, but members should present the performance of a single representative account rather than using the weighted composite of similar portfolios." Cook mentions: "True, GIPS application is not mandatory, but members should include terminated accounts as part of performance history with a clear indication of when the accounts were terminated." Whose statement is correct?

answerFeedback.89ab011c-e377-4c8e-9940-2a70b3cc7b50: Incorrect because according to Standard III(D), Performance Presentation, members should use weighted composites, not a single representative account:
answerFeedback.9665ff96-3b4b-472e-b7b6-9df670193e88: Incorrect because compliance with the GIPS Standards is not mandatory to meet obligations under Standard III(D), Performance Presentation.
answerFeedback.dc68f6a6-4d9c-4d4a-a373-8a9479c43b9b: Correct because under Standard III(D), Performance Presentation, members can meet their obligations without compliance with the GIPS Standards. Members and candidates can also meet their obligations under Standard III(D) by including terminated accounts as part of performance history with a clear indication of when the accounts were terminated.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Ethics-Lin-01
entry.itemBody:
Members should encourage their firms to establish which of the following procedures to avoid violations of Standard relating to independence and objectivity?

  • Procedure 1: Place a covered company on a restricted list if the firm is unwilling to disseminate adverse opinion on the company.
  • Procedure 2: Prohibit employees from receiving reimbursement from corporate issuers for air transportation when attending meetings at the issuers' headquarters.

answerFeedback.0978115a-f80a-4006-9939-1a0ab10c18db: Incorrect because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I(B), Independence and Objectivity, when attending meetings at an issuer’s headquarters, members and candidates should pay for commercial transportation and hotel charges. No corporate issuer should reimburse members or candidates for air transportation. Employees should not receive reimbursement from issuers even the meetings are held at the issuer's headquarters. Therefore, Procedure 2 is also correct.
answerFeedback.59fff71d-0c95-4eaf-b985-6e3d53c7aecd: Incorrect because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I(B), Independence and Objectivity, if the firm is unwilling to permit dissemination of adverse opinions about a corporate client, members and candidates should encourage the firm to remove the controversial company from the research universe and put it on a restricted list so that the firm disseminates only factual information about the company. Therefore, Procedure 1 is also correct.
answerFeedback.f2f00977-aac2-489f-b348-5266f77b9ab7:
Correct because according to the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I(B), Independence and Objectivity, if the firm is unwilling to permit dissemination of adverse opinions about a corporate client, members and candidates should encourage the firm to remove the controversial company from the research universe and put it on a restricted list so that the firm disseminates only factual information about the company. Therefore, Procedure 1 is correct.

 

In addition, according to the recommended procedures for compliance with Standard I(B), Independence and Objectivity, when attending meetings at an issuer’s headquarters, members and candidates should pay for commercial transportation and hotel charges. No corporate issuer should reimburse members or candidates for air transportation. Employees should not receive reimbursement from issuers even the meetings are held at the issuer's headquarters. Therefore, Procedure 2 is correct.

entry.title: ITEM_20170420185
entry.itemBody: Kazuya Kato, CFA, is a widely followed economist at a global investment bank. When Kato opines on economic trends, markets react by moving stock valuations considerably. When Kato receives information of a temporary oversupply of rare earth metals, he issues a forecast that price trends for rare earth metals will be down significantly on a long-term basis. Kato also secretly sells his report to a widely followed internet site. Prior to issuing this forecast, Kato emailed all portfolio managers at his bank with a copy of his report indicating that his opinion would be reversed shortly so there will be trading opportunities. Kato least likely violated which of the following CFA Institute Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct?

answerFeedback.55b465ef-9d8c-41be-b72c-ef988784082f: Correct because Kato exaggerated the potential for negative price movement with rare earth metals and violated Standard II(B), Market Manipulation, by aiming to profit on the volatility created by his actions. Standard II(B) requires that members and candidates uphold market integrity by prohibiting market manipulation. Market manipulation includes the dissemination of false or misleading information and transactions that deceive or would be likely to mislead market participants by distorting the price-setting mechanism of financial instruments. Standard IV(B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, was violated when he sold his report to the internet site. Standard VI(B), Priority of Transactions, has not been violated as it relates to investment transactions for clients and employers having priority over Member or Candidate transactions.
answerFeedback.9b411c86-c1d6-4343-bda7-188fc956d1b6: Incorrect because Standard IV(B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, was violated when he secretly sold his report to the internet site.
answerFeedback.b256c810-fd73-42f3-b9b3-ed4fc4a266ef: Incorrect because Kato exaggerated the potential for negative price movement with rare earth metals and violated Standard II(B), Market Manipulation, by aiming to profit on the volatility created by his actions. Standard II(B) requires that members and candidates uphold market integrity by prohibiting market manipulation. Market manipulation includes the dissemination of false or misleading information and transactions that deceive or would be likely to mislead market participants by distorting the price-setting mechanism of financial instruments.

entry.title: ITEM_20170420109
entry.itemBody: Joyce La Valle, CFA, is a portfolio manager at a global bank. La Valle has been told she should use a specific vendor for equity investment research that has been approved by the bank’s headquarters. Because La Valle is located in a country different from the bank’s headquarters, she is uncomfortable with the validity of the research provided by this vendor when it applies to her country and would like to use a local vendor on whom she has already conducted due diligence. Which research vendor(s) should La Valle use to avoid violating the Standards?

answerFeedback.213a6471-aaaf-45e7-a25d-827a48112553: Incorrect because when a member has reason to suspect that either secondary or third-party research or information comes from a source that lacks a sound basis (such as the bank-approved research vendor), the member must refrain from relying on that information.
answerFeedback.23d4be86-99e3-4fef-8b74-786161c3ee45: Incorrect because when a member has reason to suspect that either secondary or third-party research or information comes from a source that lacks a sound basis (such as the bank-approved research vendor), the member must refrain from relying on that information.
answerFeedback.67ecd307-8ba5-4fae-a309-e867a7a4dfd3: Correct because when a member has reason to suspect that either secondary or third-party research or information comes from a source that lacks a sound basis, the member must not rely on that information as required by Standard V(A), Diligence and Reasonable Basis.

choices.itemBody: C. Both the local and the bank-approved research vendors.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Lamba-18
entry.itemBody: Tharushi Ranasinghe, CFA, is president of a small investment firm. Most of her clients are longtime associates or family members whose investment portfolios she has managed for many years. Ranasinghe is familiar with her clients’ investment profiles and is in regular contact with them. Ranasinghe makes appropriate adjustment in her clients' portfolios following significant events in their lives. She rarely updates her clients' records given her familiarity with their investment requirements. Ranasinghe has most likely violated the Standard(s) relating to:

answerFeedback.a0436cbd-a2d7-4416-a7ce-0ab2432f0d09: Correct because Standard V(C), Record Retention states, Members and Candidates must develop and maintain appropriate records to support their investment analyses, recommendations, actions, and other investment-related communications with clients and prospective clients. In this case, Ranasinghe has a responsibility as her clients’ adviser and as the president of her company to maintain appropriate records when client circumstances change. Without necessary, relevant, and up-to-date know-your-client information, Ranasinghe would have difficulty establishing and proving that her firm has identified the needs and circumstances of its clients and has taken them into account in recommending investments. So, Ranasinghe has violated this Standard.
answerFeedback.ac183d8b-0f45-4756-93da-5db0d665430c: Incorrect because Standard III(B), Fair Dealing states that, Members and Candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. There is nothing here to suggest that Ranasinghe has violated this Standard.
answerFeedback.d8ef5250-a1d1-4831-90a4-c8cbc1876fb9: Incorrect because Standard III(B), Fair Dealing states that, Members and Candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. There is nothing here to suggest that Ranasinghe has violated this Standard. Also, Standard V(C), Record Retention states, Members and Candidates must develop and maintain appropriate records to support their investment analyses, recommendations, actions, and other investment-related communications with clients and prospective clients. In this case, Ranasinghe has a responsibility as her clients’ adviser and as the president of her company to maintain appropriate records when client circumstances change. Without necessary, relevant, and up-to-date know-your-client information, Ranasinghe would have difficulty establishing and proving that her firm has identified the needs and circumstances of its clients and has taken them into account in recommending investments. So, Ranasinghe has only violated the Standard relating to record retention.

choices.itemBody: C. both fair dealing and record retention.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Ethics-Ebeling-16
entry.itemBody: Raymond Tam, CFA, manages a fund with a mandate to invest in local equities. To improve returns for fund investors, he sells options on some of the stocks held in the fund. Three months later, the options expire and the fund reports higher returns. Tam does not mention the options in his next client update. Tam has violated the Standard(s) relating to:

answerFeedback.2472c006-9d3f-45c4-a0ca-b694a7a73847: Incorrect because Tam has not violated the standard relating to fair dealing.
answerFeedback.285c6172-acc6-465f-a0bc-888aa25104e0: Incorrect because according to Standard III(B), Fair Dealing, members and candidates must deal fairly and objectively with all clients when providing investment analysis, making investment recommendations, taking investment action, or engaging in other professional activities. Tam has treated all his clients invested in the fund the same and has therefore not violated Standard III(B).
answerFeedback.5f266f4f-4972-4ad5-b5be-a32c54f5d774: Correct because according to Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, members must disclose to clients and prospective clients the basic format and general principles of the investment processes they use to analyze investments, select securities, and construct portfolios and must promptly disclose any changes that might materially affect those processes. Even if the fund's returns have improved and the options have expired, Tam does not mention the options in his next client update and has therefore violated Standard V(B).

choices.itemBody: B. communication with clients and prospective clients only.
C. both fair dealing and communication with clients and prospective clients.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Ethics-Augulyte-04
entry.itemBody: The Standard relating to misconduct addresses:

answerFeedback.33276111-59c0-4e3c-9c58-8612a89b57cc: Incorrect because Standard I (D), Misconduct, addresses all conduct that reflects poorly on the professional integrity, good reputation, or competence of members and candidates; the Standard doesn't address all actions in members' private lives.
answerFeedback.4df8d3dc-f118-4896-b7c6-aa243e20255d: Correct because Standard I (D), Misconduct, addresses all conduct that reflects poorly on the professional integrity, good reputation, or competence of members and candidates.
answerFeedback.6bf0c5eb-7412-446b-b7e1-0bd238dea66f: Incorrect because Standard I (D), Misconduct, is primarily aimed at conduct and actions related to a member’s or candidate’s professional life.

choices.itemBody: A. only all conduct that reflects poorly on members' professional integrity.
B. only all actions violating trust in members' professional and private lives.
C. both all conduct that reflects poorly on members' professional integrity and all actions violating trust in members' professional and private lives.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05913
entry.itemBody: Suzanna Bermi, CFA, manages portfolios for retail clients. A friend asks her if Bermi can provide investment advice in Bermi's spare time. The friend offers a donation to Bermi's favorite charity in exchange for Bermi's advice. Bermi accepts the offer and starts providing investment advice to her friend immediately after sending an email to her firm's compliance department about the arrangement, including the fact that she receives no cash payments from her friend. Has Bermi most likely violated the Standards?

answerFeedback.35ae3025-cb1c-43b9-87cf-a0267f07bd04: Incorrect because Bermi has not violated Standard V(B), Communication with Clients and Prospective Clients, which requires that members and candidates disclose to clients and prospective clients the basic format and general principals of the investment processes they use to analyze investments, select securities, and construct portfolios.
answerFeedback.3b77a7c6-a928-4976-97e8-211422628d0f: Correct because Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, requires members and candidates to obtain permission from their employer before accepting compensation or other benefits from third parties for the services rendered to the employer or for any services that might create a conflict with their employer's interest. Compensation and benefits include direct compensation by the client and any indirect compensation or other benefits received from third parties. Bermi has violated this Standard because the donations to her favorite charity represent a form of compensation for services provided to her friend. In addition, her services constitute a conflict of interest with her employer since she provides a service that competes with her firm's service. Therefore, an email notification to the firm's compliance department will not suffice. Bermi has to obtain prior written permission from her employer.
answerFeedback.9345de3a-4cac-4a54-94ff-9d89c42d5458: Incorrect because Bermi has violated Standard IV (B), Additional Compensation Arrangements, by failing to obtain prior approval from her firm for providing advice to her friend.

choices.itemBody: B. Yes, the Standard relating to additional compensation arrangements
C. Yes, the Standard relating to communication with clients and prospective clients

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Brose-15
entry.itemBody: A company receives a subscription payment for a publication to be delivered next fiscal year. Ignoring income taxes, the company would recognize in the current fiscal year an increase in:

answerFeedback.1eb9dc0a-27f0-4e14-959d-fa4c3aadbf7e:
Correct because there are situations when a company receives cash in advance and actually delivers the product or service later, perhaps over a period of time. In this case, the company would record a liability for unearned revenue when the cash is initially received, and revenue would be recognized as being earned over time as products and services are delivered. An example would be a subscription payment received for a publication that is to be delivered periodically over time.

Therefore, the liability for unearned revenue would be recognized, but no revenue recognized in the P&L as the payment was for delivery in future accounting periods. The cash received would be recognized as the asset.
answerFeedback.8c054ff7-ad1a-438a-9df4-b1adc51a9a2d: Incorrect because no revenue is recognized in the P&L as the publication is to be delivered in the next fiscal year.
answerFeedback.b8679c4e-0ac9-4aac-b0fa-6768d11a606d: Incorrect because no revenue is recognized in the P&L as the publication is to be delivered in the next fiscal year.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Hung-05
entry.itemBody: Under perfect competition, the optimal firm size is at the minimum point on the:

answerFeedback.401ffef9-7d7f-437c-98c1-5ae329b60959: Correct because economies and diseconomies of scale can occur at the same time; the impact on long-run average total cost (LRAC) depends on which dominates. If economies of scale dominates, LRAC decreases with increases in output. The reverse holds true when diseconomies of scale prevail. The minimum point on the LRAC curve is referred to as the minimum efficient scale. The minimum efficient scale is the optimal firm size under perfect competition over the long run.
answerFeedback.802f76b2-7eef-44bf-8436-801faa140955: Incorrect because it is the long-run average total cost that defines the minimum efficient scale, not the short-run average variable cost. The minimum point on the LRAC curve is referred to as the minimum efficient scale. The minimum efficient scale is the optimal firm size under perfect competition over the long run.
answerFeedback.8863f423-58f0-42fe-a910-97ec8e44b0b3: Incorrect because the minimum efficient scale is the minimum point on the long-run average total cost curve, not the long-run average variable cost curve. The minimum point on the LRAC curve is referred to as the minimum efficient scale. The minimum efficient scale is the optimal firm size under perfect competition over the long run.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05176
entry.itemBody: Intangible assets are reported using the:

answerFeedback.242f0a62-8716-43c9-9e0f-f082644e6f99: Incorrect because this is not the case under either IFRS or US GAAP. IFRS allows companies to report intangible assets using either a cost model or a revaluation model. US GAAP permits only the cost model.
answerFeedback.9608014e-ba23-47d4-9c08-dd3a9628abee: Correct because IFRS allows companies to report intangible assets using either a cost model or a revaluation model.
answerFeedback.da8109d0-9bac-4557-a652-00ba05f7cf30: Incorrect because this is the answer under US GAAP, not IFRS. IFRS allows companies to report intangible assets using either a cost model or a revaluation model. US GAAP permits only the cost model.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Shaw-04
entry.itemBody: In contrast to the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI), the concentration ratio:

answerFeedback.33376855-6dad-46b6-b28c-70271926f57f: Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand. Therefore, the HHI has limited use for a financial analyst trying to estimate the potential profitability of a company or group of companies.
answerFeedback.a3e838db-361c-4ec7-811f-22ecccc0e99b: Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand. Therefore, the HHI has limited use for a financial analyst trying to estimate the potential profitability of a company or group of companies.
answerFeedback.c9f2883c-d699-4a47-a450-0945abe75a17: Correct because a disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it tends to be unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents. For example, if the largest and second-largest incumbents merge, the pricing power of the combined entity is likely to be larger than that of the two pre-existing companies. But the concentration ratio may not change much. To avoid the known issues with concentration ratios, economists O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. The HHI for the top three companies in the example in the box above would be 0.352 + 0.252 + 0.202 = 0.225 before the merger, while after the merger, it would be 0.602 + 0.202 + 0.102 = 0.410, which is substantially higher than the initial 0.225. The HHI is widely used by competition regulators.

choices.itemBody: B. accounts for the possibility of new entrants.
C. is less affected by mergers among the top market incumbents.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Econ-Islam-14
entry.itemBody: The real exchange rate for a currency:

answerFeedback.25be9b09-a803-4c66-8b85-6d97605f3249: Incorrect because although real exchange rates can exert some influence on nominal exchange rate movements, they are only one of many factors; it can be difficult to disentangle all of these inter-relationships in a complex and dynamic FX market.
answerFeedback.98a06c93-073c-4331-a2cd-cdb6aef2d40e: Correct because the real exchange rate for a currency can be constructed for the domestic currency relative to a single foreign currency or relative to a basket of foreign currencies.
answerFeedback.ea0d4aa6-c8c8-4f12-a49c-d821cbe5374a: Incorrect because real exchange rates are not quoted or traded in global FX markets: they are only indexes created by analysts to understand the international competitiveness of an economy and the real purchasing power of a currency.

choices.itemBody: A. is quoted in global foreign exchange markets.
B. can be constructed relative to a basket of other currencies.
C. is almost perfectly correlated with its nominal exchange rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08829
entry.itemBody:
An investor has the following cash flows and returns for a new account:

Year Beginning-of-Year Cash Inflow into Account Beginning-of-Year Cash Outflow from Account Return for the Year
1 €10,000 €0 –22%
2 €0 €1,000 24%

The account balance at the end of the second year is closest to:

answerFeedback.0387b1b6-6125-46d4-b2b2-8d6ac45d2aa2: Incorrect because it adds (rather than deducts) the €1,000 withdrawal in the calculation; [€10,000 × (1 – 0.22) + €1,000] × (1 + 0.24) = €10,912.
answerFeedback.d6d1b81f-61d4-48b5-b574-4c599b17fdcd: Correct because the initial deposit declines to €7,800 = €10,000 × (1 – 0.22) before the €1,000 withdrawal is made at the beginning of the second year, then the remaining balance in the account increases to €8,432, as the account earns 24% during the second year; [(€7,800 – €1,000) × (1 + 0.24)] = €8,432.
answerFeedback.fcfa06fa-a1fa-46d6-a22a-9d05cd80e9a0: Incorrect because it fails to deduct the €1,000 withdrawal from the calculation; €10,000 × (1 – 0.22) × (1 + 0.24) = €9,672.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Chan-14
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

CAD/EUR spot exchange rate 1.4356
CAD 12-month risk-free rate 2.0%
EUR 12-month risk-free rate 0.5%

CAD/EUR is the amount of CAD per 1 EUR.

The CAD/EUR 12-month forward points are closest to:

answerFeedback.0d41aef2-6a64-455c-a2d0-e16257192af5:
Correct because the 12-month forward rate is first calculated, then followed by the forward points.

• The 12-month forward rate is (CAD/EUR) x ((1 + CAD interest rate) / (1 + EUR interest rate)) = 1.4356 x ((1 + 0.02)/(1 + 0.005)) ≈ 1.4570. 

• The forward points is the difference between the forward rate and the spot rate, and scaled up by 10,000 = (1.4570 – 1.4356) x 10,000 = 214.
answerFeedback.2f9795f9-040f-40ab-bc89-de3913f787d7:
Incorrect because the forward points are wrongly multiplied by 1,000, instead of 10,000.

• The 12-month forward rate is (CAD/EUR) x ((1 + interest rate of Canada) / (1 + interest rate of Europe)) = 1.4356 x ((1 + 0.02)/(1 + 0.005)) ≈ 1.4570. 

• The forward points is the difference between forward rate and the spot rate, and scaled up wrongly by 1,000 = (1.4570 – 1.4356) x 1,000 ≈ 21.
answerFeedback.c0a3d719-9bb9-45ff-9f5f-f77c2de08bc5:
Incorrect because the 12-month forward rate is wrongly calculated.

• The 12-month forward rate is wrongly calculated as the domestic interest rate is used as numerator and the foreign interest rate is used as denominator. (CAD/EUR) x ((1 + EUR interest rate) / (1 + CAD interest rate)) = 1.4356 x ((1 + 0.005)/(1 + 0.02)) ≈ 1.4145. 

• The forward points is the difference between the forward rate and the spot rate, and scaled up by 10,000 = (1.4145 – 1.4356) x 10000 = – 211.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about machine learning is most accurate? Machine learning:

answerFeedback.18571cf1-ae94-4ba6-b48f-178334d874c0: Incorrect because ML (machine learning) models also require sufficiently large amounts of data and may not perform well where there may not be enough available data to train and validate the model.
answerFeedback.7b2adcf4-3ae7-4ea0-a087-92645804c56d: Correct because ML (machine learning) still requires human judgement in understanding the underlying data and selecting the appropriate techniques for data analysis. Before they can be used, the data must be clean and free of biases and spurious data.
answerFeedback.97ae38ab-8592-4efb-bffc-7cd981e7aa65: Incorrect because the ability to analyze Big Data using ML techniques, alongside more traditional statistical methods, represents a significant development in investment research, supported by the presence of greater data availability and advances in the algorithms themselves. Improvements in computing power and software processing speeds and falling storage costs have further supported this evolution. ML techniques are being used for Big Data analysis to help predict trends or market events, such as the likelihood of a successful merger or an outcome to a political election. Image recognition algorithms can now analyze data from satellite-imaging systems to provide intelligence on the number of consumers in retail store parking lots, shipping activity and manufacturing facilities, and yields on agricultural crops, to name just a few examples. Such information may provide insights into individual firms or at national or global levels and may be used as inputs into valuation or economic models. Thus, there is rather broad application of ML in Big Data analysis, which is expected to develop further.

choices.itemBody: A. does not have a broad application in Big Data analysis.
B. still requires human judgment in understanding the underlying data.
C. performs well even when insufficient data are available to train and validate the model.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Brose-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following requires management to report on the effectiveness of the company’s internal control over financial reporting in accordance with the Sarbanes–Oxley Act?

answerFeedback.45574014-3902-407d-a230-c834beef3e70: Incorrect because the IASB is the independent standard-setting body of the IFRS Foundation, an independent, not-for-profit private sector organization. The principle objectives of the IFRS Foundation are to develop and promote the use and adoption of a single set of high quality financial standards; to ensure the standards result in transparent, comparable, and decision-useful information while taking into account the needs of a range of sizes and types of entities in diverse economic settings; and to promote the convergence of national accounting standards and IFRS.
answerFeedback.51da59bb-dbb5-4caf-9cb8-02904c1515a0: Incorrect because the Sarbanes–Oxley Act of 2002 created the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) to oversee auditors. The SEC (not FASB) is responsible for carrying out the requirements of the act and overseeing the PCAOB. The act requires management to report on the effectiveness of the company’s internal control over financial reporting (including obtaining external auditor confirmation of the effectiveness of internal control).
answerFeedback.b676ba47-948c-4282-8e0e-078266276783: Correct because the Sarbanes–Oxley Act of 2002 created the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) to oversee auditors. The SEC is responsible for carrying out the requirements of the act and overseeing the PCAOB. The act requires management to report on the effectiveness of the company’s internal control over financial reporting (including obtaining external auditor confirmation of the effectiveness of internal control).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-CorpIssuers-Moustra-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following capital investments would most likely be classified as a going concern project?

answerFeedback.30c884c1-df98-4fa1-af9c-f2934f978979: Incorrect because projects to explore a new technology or innovation opportunity and are considered new lines of business.
answerFeedback.703a84af-9a64-4feb-a7f3-97a02852053a: Correct because going concern projects often known as maintenance capital expenditures, are investments to continue the company’s current operations and maintain the existing size of the business. Common going concern projects include replacing assets nearing the end of their useful life, maintaining IT hardware and software, and continuous improvements of existing facilities. Upgrade of older production facilities to reduce costs falls under going concern projects.
answerFeedback.a66f2b09-62fb-494b-9748-4bd0e7b8ba11: Incorrect because this project falls under category of regulatory/compliance projects.

choices.itemBody: A. Upgrade of older production facilities to reduce costs
B. Modification of production processes to comply with new regulation
C. Funding research on the creation of new products based on an innovative technology

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-FSAN-Young-09
entry.itemBody: A company's purchases can be estimated as cost of sales plus:

answerFeedback.93079cd1-c8f5-4fcc-bde4-ee48c911bf25: Correct because if the amount of purchases is not directly available, it can be computed as cost of goods sold plus ending inventory less beginning inventory. Alternatively, cost of goods sold is sometimes used as an approximation of purchases.
answerFeedback.ae57142f-5b90-453c-91b1-cc631cfc0fd6: Incorrect because if the amount of purchases is not directly available, it can be computed as cost of goods sold plus ending inventory less beginning inventory. Alternatively, cost of goods sold is sometimes used as an approximation of purchases.
answerFeedback.b5b988f6-72be-4215-a085-d0efcfcb6c8f: Incorrect because if the amount of purchases is not directly available, it can be computed as cost of goods sold plus ending inventory less beginning inventory. Alternatively, cost of goods sold is sometimes used as an approximation of purchases.

choices.itemBody: A. ending inventory less beginning inventory.
B. beginning inventory less ending inventory.
C. the average level of inventory for the period.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Quant 01KGL
entry.itemBody: If a security appreciates by 33% over the first six months and then depreciates by 15% over the following six months, the holding period return over the 12-month period is closest to:

answerFeedback.2715bfaa-2bc8-48d8-b047-fef96bd5b2e6: Incorrect because it is the geometric mean of the two six-month HPRs; √[(1 + 0.33) × (1 – 0.15)] – 1 = 0.06325 ≈ 6.3%.
answerFeedback.8734aa86-6eda-4645-b5c9-3634da61efd4: Incorrect because it is the addition of the two six-month HPRs; (0.33 – 0.15) = 0.18 = 18.0%.
answerFeedback.d670f2bd-5979-47b5-ba22-5fcaa8ab11fb: Correct because a holding period return is the return earned from holding an asset for a single specified period of time. This return can be generalized and shown as a mathematical expression in which P is the price and I is the income:  R = (P1 − P0 + I1)/P0, where P0 is the initial investment, P1 is the price received at the end of the holding period, and I1 is the cash paid by the investment. Also, link or compound holding period returns to obtain an annual rate of return for the year (the time-weighted rate of return for the year). HPR1 = 0.33 and HPR2 = –0.15, such that the rate of return over the 12-month period = (1 + 0.33)(1 – 0.15) – 1 = 0.1305 ≈ 13.1%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10920
entry.itemBody: With respect to the monetary transmission mechanism, a central bank's policy rate is initially transmitted through the economy via:

answerFeedback.0ceb7c25-8580-4735-b3f5-f31c12b0f156: Incorrect because central banks have three primary tools available to them: open market operations,the refinancing rate, and reserve requirements. Moreover, the third primary way in which central banks can limit or increase the supply of money in an economy is via their reserve requirements. Consequently, the reserve requirements represent a primary tool of the central bank to control the amount of money in circulation, not a channel through which the central bank transmits its interest rate.
answerFeedback.6f8aff18-e902-44e0-a6e9-194054d0289c: Correct because the implementation of the policy may begin to work through the economy via four interrelated channels. Those channels include bank lending rates, asset prices, agents' expectations, and exchange rates.
answerFeedback.e855e954-a292-49ad-886f-622d65346818: Incorrect because the base rates of commercial banks and interbank rates should rise in response to the increase in the official rate. Banks would, in turn, increase the cost of borrowing for individuals and companies over both short- and long-term horizons. Businesses and consumers would then tend to borrow less as interest rates rise. Market participants would then come to the view that higher interest rates will lead to slower economic growth, reduced profits, and reduced borrowing to finance asset purchases. Weaker total demand would tend to put downward pressure on the rate of domestic inflation as would a stronger currency, which would reduce the prices of imports. Taken together, these might begin to put downward pressure on the overall measure of inflation. Consequently, a change in the central bank's interest rate does not get transmitted through the economy via inflation, as the latter is the end result and not a transmission channel.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Chua-15
entry.itemBody: For a sample size of 10 and sum of squared differences in ranks of 118, the Spearman rank correlation is closest to:

answerFeedback.4b289a66-7231-4305-93d5-789653bc0787: Incorrect because this is the answer if the candidate forgets to include '1 –' in the formula, and instead calculates the rank correlation as [6∑i=1ndi2] / [n(n2 – 1)] = 6(118) / [10(102 – 1)] = 0.71515 ≈ 0.72.
answerFeedback.50aae596-f65e-42da-bcaf-898f5fc91f19: Incorrect because this is the answer if the candidate uses n2 instead of n in the first factor of the denominator, calculating the rank correlation as 1 – [6∑i=1ndi2] / [n2(n2 – 1)] = 1 – 6(118) / [102(102 – 1)] = 0.92848 ≈ 0.93.
answerFeedback.f082726e-6250-44b0-a805-d1005e3d87de:
Correct because with n as the sample size, the Spearman rank correlation is given by 

rs = 1 – [6∑i=1ndi2] / [n(n2 – 1)] = 1 – 6(118) / [10(102 – 1)] = 0.28485 ≈ 0.28.

Note that ∑i=1ndi2 = sum of squared differences in ranks = 118, as given.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06852
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € thousands) about a company:

Beginning retained earnings 1,500
Ending retained earnings 2,000
Dividends declared and paid 400

If there are no other items affecting shareholders' equity, net income (in € thousands) is:

answerFeedback.5db95e58-afbb-433c-babf-4fb5a3a450f3: Correct because ending retained earnings = beginning retained earnings + net income – dividends; 2,000 = 1,500 + net income – 400; net income = 900.
answerFeedback.71b775ce-9d66-41ba-b67a-c84649e08cbf: Incorrect because it adds dividends in the calculation of ending retained earnings instead of subtracting. Ending retained earnings = beginning retained earnings + net income + dividends; 2,000 = 1,500 + net income + 400; net income = 100.
answerFeedback.ec30a8e4-63ea-47f7-a65e-cc2424ed012f: Incorrect because it ignores dividends in the calculation of ending retained earnings. Ending retained earnings = beginning retained earnings + net income; 2,000 = 1,500 + net income; net income = 500.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Croitoru-09
entry.itemBody: Compared to the normal distribution, the lognormal distribution is more appropriate to model asset prices because it:

answerFeedback.24afd346-77dd-4959-b6ad-d1e085139f83: Incorrect because both lognormal and normal distributions are completely defined by two parameters, mean and standard deviation. However, the reason why the lognormal distribution is better suited to model asset prices is that it is bounded below by 0, unlike the normal distribution whose outcomes span the entire real line.
answerFeedback.997aea03-038a-4f07-8506-a7cfd43f580c: Incorrect because the two most noteworthy observations about the lognormal distribution are that it is bounded below by 0 and it is skewed to the right (not to the left) (it has a long right tail). Therefore, the lognormal distribution has a positive skewness.
answerFeedback.d88eb6de-97a2-4ab6-94e7-ea592509beca: Correct because the two most noteworthy observations about the lognormal distribution are that it is bounded below by 0 and it is skewed to the right (it has a long right tail).  In practice, the lognormal distribution has been found to be a usefully accurate description of the distribution of prices for many financial assets. However, the normal distribution is often a good approximation for returns.

choices.itemBody: B. has a defined boundary to the left.
C. is completely defined by two parameters.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FRA 05AML
entry.itemBody: Unless it is impractical to do so, which of the following is reported through retrospective application?

answerFeedback.16c8669b-72b0-4e44-90d2-83b6b2736ea1: Correct because changes in accounting policies are reported through retrospective application unless it is impractical to do so. Retrospective application means that the financial statements for all fiscal years shown in a company’s financial report are presented as if the newly adopted accounting principle had been used throughout the entire period.
answerFeedback.b4cc6abb-4133-44e3-b01a-3d226deab089: Incorrect because while changes in accounting policies are reported through retrospective application unless it is impractical to do so. Changes in accounting estimates are handled prospectively, with the change affecting the financial statements for the period of change and future periods. No adjustments are made to prior statements.
answerFeedback.c97a28bd-cf5d-4ac9-91c5-ada48e2c7fd6: Incorrect because changes in accounting estimates are handled prospectively, with the change affecting the financial statements for the period of change and future periods. No adjustments are made to prior statements.

choices.itemBody: C. Both changes in accounting policies and accounting estimates

entry.title: ITEM_20170608321
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding inventory valuation is most accurate?

answerFeedback.16b10cfb-48b1-46f9-bbf0-dac8a49a16e3: Correct. Both IFRS and US GAAP allow agricultural inventories to be valued at net realizable value.
answerFeedback.591af2cd-34ff-4cdc-83ac-998223d50514: Incorrect. IFRS defines net realizable value as selling price less costs to get it ready to sell and to make the sale.
answerFeedback.6e44bac2-4a2b-4058-ac95-aa33ee395e47: Incorrect. US GAAP does not allow reversal of a write-down generally.

choices.itemBody: A. IFRS defines market value as net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
B. Both IFRS and US GAAP allow the reversal of write-downs back to the original cost.
C. Both IFRS and US GAAP allow agricultural inventories to be valued at net realizable value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03448
entry.itemBody: If wages and prices are rigid, which of the following policy combinations most likely leads to an increase in aggregate demand from the private sector relative to the public sector?

answerFeedback.784ce3d5-969a-4ab8-a8e0-62fd0c5aad78: Incorrect because, under the assumption that wages and prices are rigid, if taxes are cut or government spending rises, the expansionary fiscal policy will lead to an increase in aggregate output. If this is accompanied by a reduction in money supply to offset the fiscal expansion, then interest rates will increase and have a negative effect on private sector demand. We have higher output and higher interest rates, and government spending will be a larger proportion of overall national income.
answerFeedback.8e69f4bc-8d79-4203-a5ab-b160703d23a3: Correct because, under the assumption that wages and prices are rigid, if a fiscal contraction is accompanied by expansionary monetary policy and low interest rates, then the private sector will be stimulated and will increase as a share of GDP, while the public sector will shrink.
answerFeedback.e5017411-21da-48dc-b640-a867ebb9778a: Incorrect because, under the assumption that wages and prices are rigid, if both fiscal and monetary policy are easy, then the joint impact will be highly expansionary leading to an increase in aggregate demand, lower interest rates (at least if the monetary impact is larger), and growing private and public sectors.

choices.itemBody: A. Easy fiscal policy and easy monetary policy
B. Easy fiscal policy and tight monetary policy
C. Tight fiscal policy and easy monetary policy

entry.title: ITEM_20170608348
entry.itemBody: Accounting choices within US GAAP that decrease reported performance in the current period and may increase performance in later periods are most likely examples of:

answerFeedback.5f706137-1cce-442a-aa5e-5e6a0fc12cb1: Correct because conservative accounting choices decrease the company’s reported performance and financial position in the current period and may increase its reported performance and financial position in later periods.
answerFeedback.70f6da59-3b98-49d2-8121-663d085fb84a: Incorrect because aggressive accounting choices have the opposite effect of increasing the company’s reported performance and financial position in the current period and may decrease its reported performance and financial position in later periods.
answerFeedback.cb708191-fd72-4f6d-9035-da1f68867c8e: Incorrect because conservative accounting such as decreasing current reported performance and increasing later reported performance does not typically create a sustainability issue.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608236
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, a decrease in which of the following financial metrics would most likely result in a lower return on equity (ROE)?

answerFeedback.0b897afd-78cd-43bc-bc65-8aacd378cac3:
Incorrect because the tax burden is one of the components of ROE in the 5-factor model:

Tax burden = Net income/EBT = (EBT – Tax)/EBT = 1 – Tax/EBT = 1 – Effective tax rate

A lower tax rate means the company keeps more of its pre-tax profits (and has a higher tax burden). A lower tax rate increases net income and increases ROE: an increase in any of the 5 components increases ROE.
answerFeedback.114ed90e-9d7b-4fb6-93d3-06e5d2fb3137: Incorrect because days of sales outstanding is a component of the asset turnover measure. All else equal, if days of sales outstanding decreased, total asset turnover would increase. If asset turnover increases, so will return on equity.
answerFeedback.858c2f74-1b09-4c65-b900-a1e9f1414dca:
Correct because leverage is a component of the return on equity equation under the DuPont Analysis. If leverage decreases, so will return on equity.

ROE = Tax burden × Interest burden × Earnings before interest and taxes margin × Total asset turnover × Leverage

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Econ-Islam-02
entry.itemBody: In monopolistic competition, the level of output that minimizes average cost is:

answerFeedback.2ea3cf28-ebe2-414f-a4e4-7d1f194ff1d2: Incorrect because unlike long-run equilibrium in perfect competition, in the market of monopolistic competition, the equilibrium position is at a higher level of average cost (i.e., the lower level of output) than the level of output that minimizes average cost.
answerFeedback.b0707e0d-00f6-4d40-8446-dde1990d259b: Correct because unlike long-run equilibrium in perfect competition, in the market of monopolistic competition, the equilibrium position is at a higher level of average cost (i.e., the lower level of output) than the level of output that minimizes average cost.
answerFeedback.cfa21968-6237-44ea-bfd3-47c11bc863c0: Incorrect because unlike long-run equilibrium in perfect competition, in the market of monopolistic competition, the equilibrium position is at a higher level of average cost (i.e., the lower level of output) than the level of output that minimizes average cost.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the actual level of output in the long run.
B. equal to the actual level of output in the long run.
C. greater than the actual level of output in the long run.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-FSAN-Burke-01
entry.itemBody: Organic growth represents changes in revenue due to the impact of changes in:
